facts.text: Appellant purchased premises in Vile Parle, Bombay in 1945.
Under appellant's predecessor-in-title, tenant Thirumal Rao Potdar occupied a room at monthly rent of Rs. 20 including water rate of Rs. 2, with municipal tap water supply.
After appellant's purchase, Thirumal Rao continued tenancy on same terms.
Municipal water supply cut off early May 1947 due to predecessor's default in municipal taxes; tenants used well water from neighbouring tenant thereafter.
Thirumal Rao died in or about 1950; his widow (first respondent) continued in occupation, paying original rent plus annas 10 permitted increase (Rs. 20-10-0), without municipal water.
Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 (Act LVII of 1947) came into force on February 13, 1948.
Tenancy recorded in first respondent's name some time in 1951.
In April 1954, first respondent informed Municipal authorities that water supply stopped since 1947.
Municipality replied on May 24, 1954, that water connection could be restored on payment of Rs. 11-4-0 fee if owner's consent produced.

First respondent's pleader wrote to appellant demanding refund of Rs. 72 (Rs. 2/month water for 3 years post-mutation), restoration of water connection, alleging withholding due to non-payment of dues; threatened prosecution under s.24.
Appellant refused/neglected to restore water connection.
First respondent filed complaint on June 14, 1954, for prosecution under s.24.
Appellant convicted by 7th Presidency Magistrate, Dadar, on March 24, 1955: 1 day simple imprisonment + Rs.150 fine (1 month SI in default).
Revision to Bombay High Court dismissed summarily on April 22, 1955.
Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court refused by Division Bench on May 16, 1955.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on October 10, 1955.

legal_issues.text: Whether an offence punishable under s.24 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 has been brought home to the appellant.

Whether the constituent elements of offence under s.24(1) are satisfied: (a) withholding essential supply (water) without just or sufficient cause, attributable to landlord; (b) whether the supply was 'enjoyed by the tenant' at a time when the Act was in force.
Meaning of 'enjoyed by the tenant': actual use or mere right to enjoy; whether enjoyment in remote past (pre-Act) suffices or must be post-Act coming into force.

petitioner_arguments.text: Raised a number of contentions against conviction and sentence.
Supply cut off by Municipality due to predecessor's default, not appellant's act; appellant not directly responsible.
Tenant did not enjoy supply after Act came into force; enjoyment must be during Act's operation, not remote past.

respondent_arguments.text: Tenant had right to enjoy water supply as part of tenancy terms; 'enjoyed' means had the right, not physical use.
Omission to restore supply attributable to landlord per Explanation II.

court_reasoning.text: Water supply is essential supply per Explanation I; withholding attributable to landlord via omission to pay Rs.11-4-0 for restoration, per Explanation II (1953).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant continued to withhold essential supply.

court_reasoning.text: Second ingredient essential: supply must have been enjoyed by tenant when Act in force (post-1948); cut off in 1947 pre-Act, tenant used well water thereafter, no enjoyment under Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No enjoyment by tenant at time Act operative.

court_reasoning.text: 'Enjoyed' means actual/physical enjoyment until cut off, not mere right or remote past use; sub-s.(3) indicates recent enjoyment; strict construction as penal/extraordinary remedy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Straining 'enjoyed' to mean 'right to enjoy' not permissible; avoids ex post facto issue.

court_reasoning.text: s.24 provisions construed as whole; sub-s.(2),(3) depend on contravention of (1); pre-1953, doubtful if Municipality's act attributable without Expl.II.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Strict interpretation required for inroads on landlord's rights.

holdings.text: Offence under s.24 requires tenant's enjoyment of essential supply at time Act in force; pre-Act cut-off with no post-Act enjoyment means no offence.
'Enjoyed by the tenant' in s.24 means actual enjoyment, not mere contractual right.
Withholding includes omissions attributable to landlord causing local authority cut-off (Expl.II).

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 (Act LVII of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Central provision defining offence of withholding essential supply without cause; court interprets elements strictly.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act 61 of 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Inserted Expl.II attributing local authority cut-offs to landlord.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits ex post facto penal laws; supports requiring post-Act enjoyment.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds offence under s.24 not established due to lack of tenant's enjoyment of water supply after Act's commencement; conviction and sentence set aside.

key_quotes.text: The only question for determination in this appeal, is whether an offence punishable under s.24 of the Bombay Rents Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act LVII of 1947 has been brought home to the appellant.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In our opinion, the section makes it essential that the particular essential supply should have been available for the use of the tenant at some time when the Act was in force.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on temporal requirement for 'enjoyment'.

key_quotes.text: It would be straining the language of the section to say that enjoyed should mean had the right to enjoy.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Such remedies which are inroads upon the landlords freedom of action, have to be construed strictly in accordance with the words actually used by the Legislature.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle of strict construction for penal provisions.
